subject: Advent is getting closer
header: Christmas is getting close and before that there is the tradition of creating Advent calendars. In the Perl world it means a series of articles, one article every day in the 3 weeks leading up t Christmas. It is a community project so you can also contribute an article or two. See the advent section for more details.

entries.text: Damien Krotkine became the maintainer of the Redis Perl module and started his reign by creating a mailing list for the Redis Perl users and developers.

entries.title: The Stratopan Beta Is Here
entries.text: Jeffrey Ryan Thalhammer has opened the gates of Stratopan. (You might recall, it is the cloud-hosted version Pinto, that gives you control over all your Perl-dependencies so they will be upgrade only when you want it. There is also a promise to get unlimited access to Stratopan for life if you sign up soon. I already have an account.

entries.title: Windows Shell to Perl Program
entries.text: JT Smith writes about the MadMongers meeting where they took a bat file (a Windows shell script) and converted it to a Perl script. It became much longer, so besides having fun, I am not sure what is the advantage here. Unless they plan to wrap some of the functionality in modules so they become reusable and then the actual script becomes short again.

entries.title: Don't Get Bent Out of Shape About Being Cross Platform
entries.text: Timm Murray, who came out from the Wumpus Cave just to attend the MadMongers meeting, has his own opinion on how much one should invest in turning a script to be platform independent. Especially when there is no immediate need to run the script on other platforms.

entries.text: Apparently I missed the Tiny Code Quiz Ovid posted last week, but now chromatic took upon the task to try to explain the seemingly (?) unexpected behaviour of perl.

entries.title: Larry Wall: 5 Programming Languages Everyone Should Know
entries.text: 6:13 minutes - part of the BigThink interview.

entries.title: Introduction to the Perl Data Language (PDL)
entries.text: 51:22 min talk by David Mertens giving some 'simple' (as in simple astrophysics :) example and then a bunch of resource to make it easier to get started. The approach is interesting as he keeps telling why is it better to use PDL than C, but only once does he mention the advantages of PDL over pure Perl.

entries.title: The way to write Ruby + Middleman application with Perl.
entries.text: Middleman is ruby web framework that makes developing stand-alone websites simple.  Yuki Kimoto shows an example using Mojolicious. One of the commenters point to similar solution in Dancer, and yet another commenter points to Poet which is modern web framework for Mason developers.

entries.title: How to have several Catalyst apps behind one Apache server
entries.text: Tara L Andrews uses Plack::Middleware::ReverseProxyPath and a shell script to solve this.

entries.title: moving my homedir into the 21st century
entries.text: Ricardo Signes tells us about the pair programming session he had with Ingy döt Net and Frew Schmidt, and how it lead him to switch from 'screen' to 'tmux'. He also talks about the dotfile manager he has started to use.

entries.title: Multi dimensional hashes in Perl
entries.text: Perl only has one-dimensional hashes, but each value in a has can be a reference to another hash. Or an array. This, together with autovivification allows the creation of very flexible data structures.
